Lily, in negligee, lying on couch, face covered by newspa she is reading while she has breakfast, which is on a lit table beside her. The dishes are clean but cheap looking. Lily lowers the paper and looks slyly up. She sees:
Gaston, in dressing gown, sitting in armchair, reading a  newspaper.

She watches Gaston, looks down to table, back at Gaston.  She wants to put something over without being seen-- something important. Now, quick, she decides to do it, co what may. She picks up a French roll--still watching him- dunks it in the coffee, takes a hurried bite, and  disappears again behind paper.
(looking up from the paper) I don't agree with this review at  all. I thought Martini's singing  was adequate, but to call him a  great singer--ridiculous!
Still reading her paper.
(without looking up) I always liked him. Especially last  year in Munich ...
(drops paper) Last year? It can't be that long.
(drops paper) Yes! Don't you remember the day you  took that Chinese vase from the  Royal Palace  (with tenderness)  and made it into a lamp for my night  table?
He looks at her with emotion, gets up, and goes to her.
Gaston sits close to her, caresses her hair.

I remember the lamp, I remember the  night table, and I remember the  night.  (They kiss.)  Everything will be all right again.  (As he gets up; with a  valiant little smile.)  Prosperity is just around the corner! He goes out of the picture. Lily smiles after him with to confidence.
Gaston returns, sits, picks up paper, resumes reading.
at her paper. Suddenly she stares at something on the pag She leaps to her feet.

He looks up.
Paper in hand, followed by camera, she goes to the bureau opens a drawer, and takes out Mariette's handbag. She loo at the bag, rereads the item in the paper, looks back aga
Puzzled, he gets up.
Followed by camera, she hastens to Gaston, hands him the  paper, points to the item.
Read this.
A large classified ad with headline: Handbag Lost--Twenty Thousand Francs Reward. Before we can read the rest, came moves close to the headline. Under the insert, we hear:
The description fits. That's our  bag!
Gaston has finished reading.

Twenty thousand francs ... If we  sold it we'd get--  (He takes the bag from  Lily, examines it like  an expert.)  Well, it's worth forty thousand at  the most. She paid probably sixty  thousand. When we sell it ... I'd  say five thousand.
Darling, then let's be honest and  return it to the lady.
And take the twenty thousand francs ...
Right.
(with sudden emotion) Sweetheart, what day is today?
The fourteenth of May.
And tomorrow is the fifteenth. And  the day after tomorrow--
(not knowing what he wants) The six--
She catches Gaston's eye. Her face lights up. Very tender she embraces him.
We'll go to Venice, to the same hotel!
(romantically) We'll take the Royal Suite!
Two fifty-three, five--
Seven and nine!
And we'll celebrate the second  anniversary of the day we didn't get  married!
Darling! They kiss. After they have held the embrace a few moments we hear a knock  the door. They look toward the door, hid the handbag instantly.
Come in.

Mariette and an elderly woman who has seen better days. H clothes, once elegant, now are shabby. She is unwrapping package as camera moves toward both to a close shot. She  takes out a handbag which also seen better days, holds it toward Mariette pathetically. Mariette responds with a  kindly look.
No, I'm sorry, but that's not the  bag.
(restraining a sob) I know it isn't. But it's pretty-- isn't it?
(sympathetic) Very pretty.
We hear phone ring. Mariette, annoyed at the interruption goes out of the picture.
Mariette enters, picks up phone.

Hello ... Yes .. . Where did you  find the bag?  (Amused.)  Where?  (Even more amused.)  Where? What?  (Smiling broadly.)  What was in it?  (With a change of  expression, outraged.)  How dare you!  (She slams down  receiver.)
bag in hand, with patient hope.
at phone. Her expression softens. Followed by camera, she goes to woman.
You wouldn't have any use for it?  (Mariette hesitates.)  You see, I have another bag, and I  really don't need this. So, if you'd  like to buy it ...
Mariette sees tears in the woman's eyes.
(reaching into drawer  of nearby table) Would two hundred francs be sufficient?
(this is much more  than she expected) Yes, madame.
Mariette hands her the money.
(overwhelmed) Oh, thank you, madame!
She goes out of picture toward door. Mariette looks after her with compassion, which is broken by the ringing phone Increasingly annoyed, she goes to phone, newly purchased  bag in hand.
Mariette enters edgily.
Hello ... Yes ...
She tosses handbag out of picture.
Bag falls on armchair into an assortment of several other bags. Mariette must have been buying bags for hours.
What? Yes, this is Madame Colet.
at the phone
What? Yes, I lost my bag. Yes. Last  night at the opera ... No, no, I  don't want to buy a piano!  (She hangs up angrily.)

Shooting from the direction of the living room toward the house entrance door. Hall is filled with men and women,  some well dressed, some shabby. Some carry packages. Seve women hold, each, two "found" bags. One woman carries a  crying baby. Butler's voice comes behind the camera.
Next, please. A young Russian Bolshevik, unshaven, with bushy hair, mov toward camera.
at open door. Bolshevik enters, followed by butler, who  shuts door behind them as Bolshevik goes to Mariette.  During all this, we hear:
No ... No, it was not insured. But  right now it's too late.
What? (Bolshevik enters.)  I may lose it again? But I haven't  found it yet! I'm sorry. Goodbye!  (She turns toward  Bolshevik distracted)  Yes?
(heavy Russian accent) So you lost a handbag, madame?
(impatiently) Yes.
And it had diamonds in the back.
Yes.
And diamonds in the front.
Yes.
Diamonds all over.
Well, have you found it?
(screaming) No!  (Raising his arm  like a prophet.)  But let me tell you--any woman who  spends a fortune in times like these  for a handbag--phooey, phooey,  phooey!
Butler enters officiously.
(to Bolshevik) I must ask you
(brushing butler aside) And as Trotsky said--  (in Russian)  "Any woman who spends a fortune for  a silk purse is a sow's ear."  (In English.)  And that goes for you, too!
to hall. While Bolshevik is ranting, it opens; Gaston  enters briskly with an authoritative air, shuts door behi him.
Mariette is startled; she doesn't know who or what the  gentleman is. Bolshevik is frightened. Butler is  momentarily nonplussed.
He steps forward commandingly.

Gaston goes to Bolshevik, puts his arm patronizingly on h shoulder, and tells him politely but emphatically, in  Russian, to leave. Bolshevik makes a protesting remark.  Gaston tells him vigorously and effectively to scram. Cow the Bolshevik goes.
Butler, recuperated and full of dignity, opens door to th hall. Bolshevik appears, turns to Mariette and Gaston.
(in a final outburst) Phooey! Phooey! And--  (Looking for another word but failing to find it;  twice as loud.)  Phooey!  Butler shoves him out, follows, shuts door.
Mariette and Gaston. Mariette is more bewildered by Gasto than by the Bolshevik.
(looking after the  departed man) His phooey is worse than his bite.  (Turning to Mariette.)  I must apologize for entering  unannounced. If I am not mistaken,  Madame Colet?
Yes...?
Will you be good enough to look at  this bag, madame?  (He brings the bag  forth, hands it to  Mariette.)
(with instant and  joyful recognition)  That's it! Yes, that's it! ...  Jacques!
It opens and butler enters.
Yes, madame?
Dismiss all the people in the hall.  The bag has been found.
Very well, madame.

And Jacques. Call up the major and  tell him-- No, don't call him. Let  him keep on searching! And Jacques--  (Phone rings. Mariette  picks up receiver and  speaks before the other  party can speak.)  Sorry--the bag's been found.  (She hangs up.)  And Jacques--
Yes, madame?
Call Cohen, Cohen, Ginsburg, and  Renault. Give my thanks to M'sieu  Renault.  (In high spirits.)  Thank them all!
Very well, madame.
We hear door closing. Mariette looks happily at bag, turn to Gaston.
Where did you--
She discovers that Gaston is no longer standing beside he She looks around.
A beautiful Chinese vase on a table. Gaston, looking at  vase with appraising eye, is absorbed, unaware that  Mariette has addressed him.
She goes toward Gaston.
still studying the vase. Mariette appears. He turns to he
(happily) Where did you find it?
You know the main staircase in the  opera?
Yes.
Then you go to the left. There's a  landing.
(eagerly) Yes.
Then you go into the foyer.
Yes.
And as you leave the foyer, there is  a little niche.
I know that niche.
And in that niche, there is a  statue of Venus.
I remember.
(irrelevantly) You like that statue?
(nonplussed) Not particularly.
Neither do I.  (Without any transition.)  That's where I found it.
(naively, not suspicious) I don't know how I could have lost  it there.  I was nowhere near that  niche.
Oh ... That's strange. Maybe--are  you sure this is your bag?
(a little nettled) Of course it is! Are you doubting  me?
(polite but precise) Not in the least, madame. But you  see, it's a very expensive bag--one  has to be careful.
(half-annoyed, half-laughing,  and a little conceited) Well--I am Madame Colet.
(urbanely) And I am M'sieu Laval--if you will  allow me to introduce myself.
Mariette is perplexed. Their relationship has somehow bee transformed. She is uncertain. Then she yields.
(With a little laugh;  extending her hand) Well--how do you do, M'sieu Laval?
The pleasure is mine, madame.
He bends over and kisses her hand. Camera goes quickly to close-up of a beautiful diamond ring. As he kisses the ha Gaston's eye appraises the ring.
FranГ§ois, package under arm, walking. It is apparent tha he has purchased the handbag.
at table. Gaston has just opened the bag.
(With the air of an honest  man taking inventory) One purse--  (shaking it)  empty. One vanity case--  (opening it)
But really, m'sieu, this isn't  necessary.

Please, Madame Colet, I believe in  doing things correctly. Shall we  continue?  (He empties the bag.)  Two hairpins, one cigarette lighter,  one box of real matches, and-- Oh,  yes, this letter from Major--
(quickly) Oh! You didn't read it!
Naturally I did.
Oh!
You needn't be embarrassed, madame.  A lady as charming as you would, and  should, get love letters.
(embarrassed and flattered) M'sieu Laval!

But one suggestion, madame.  (Shaking his head.)  Not the major.  (Mariette looks startled,  as if to say, "How did  you know?")  I don't  mind his grammatical  mistakes. I'll overlook his bad  punctuation. But the letter has no  mystery--no bouquet--no ...  (Changing the subject,  taking a lipstick out  of bag.)  And one lipstick ...  (Reading markings on  bottom; disapproving.)  Scarlet number four.
What's wrong now?
With your skin, I prefer crimson.
(now on a vital theme) Too much blue in crimson.
That's what you need!
No, no, no!  (She sits on couch.  He sits beside her.)  I disagree with you completely! I  tried it once--
What shade of powder do you use?
Peaches and cream.
That's too dark.
(fighting for her life) Do you realize I have light eyes?
But, Madame Colet, that's a matter  of eye shadow. I can straighten that  out in two seconds. We hear a knock on the door.
(annoyed at interruption) Come in!
Butler comes in, shuts door quickly behind him.
(With a sour expression) The major.
On couch. She makes a gesture of exasperation. So does  Gaston. They look at each other helplessly. Then Gaston  takes charge. He rises and goes toward butler.
at living room door. Major stands waiting. Door opens;  butler comes out, followed briskly by Gaston.
(before Major can speak) I'm sorry, m'sieu, but Madame had  better not see anyone.
Major stares blankly. He never saw Gaston before.

You see, the bag has just been  found, and the reaction of relief  from her former excitement and  strain is just a little too much  for her. It's not very serious, but  just the same we'd better not take  any chances.
(assuming Gaston  is a physician) Just as you say, Doctor.
Thank you, Major.  (Goes back toward  living room.)
Good day, Doctor.
Good day, Major.
The camera goes with Major toward entrance door. Major  looks crestfallen.

in front of Mariette's house. FranГ§ois, followed by came goes to the door, rings bell. Door is opened by butler, a Major comes out, butler remaining in doorway. Major and  FranГ§ois stare at each other. Major looks pointedly at  FranГ§ois's package. Then Major turns to butler.
Jacques, has the bag been found?
Yes, Major.
Major turns with bright smile to FranГ§ois, who looks glu and glances instinctively at his package.
Is Madame feeling well?
No, Major. Major is still looking at the unhappy FranГ§ois and havin the time of life.
Is Madame seeing anybody this  afternoon, this evening, or even  tomorrow?
No, Major.
You may shut the door, Jacques. Butler closes door. FranГ§ois, miserable, turns away from Major.
Well. that leaves you holding the  bag. Goodbye! Major lifts his hat, goes out of picture to right. FranГ§ looks after him angrily, then goes out of picture to left
Gaston and Mariette. There is a moment of silence.
(rising) Well, I think I'd better be going.  Goodbye, Madame Colet.
(rising) Goodbye, M'sieu La-- Oh, yes ...  This is a rather delicate matter and  I don't want to ... You see, if you  read my advertisement carefully, you  must have noticed that there was ...
In other words, madame, it  embarrasses you to offer me the  twenty thousand francs reward.
Yes.

Don't be embarrassed, madame. I'll  take it. I need the money. I wish I  were in a position to ignore the  whole matter. But you know, madame,  the stock market, bank crash ... To  make a long story short--a member  of the nouveaux poor.
(looks at him sympathetically) Then I'm glad I lost the bag! I'll  write you the check immediately.  (Followed by camera, she goes.)
at staircase. Coming from living room, Mariette goes up t stairs, followed by camera. At first landing, as Mariette reaches door--
Madame Colet!
(turning)  Yes, M'sieu Laval?
Shooting down from her angle.
Do you know my first name?
No. What is it? Tell me.
Followed by camera, he runs up stairs. At the landing, he goes close to her.
(whispering ardently) Gaston! She looks at him with a confused smile.
(Still ardently) And do you know what I'd like to  have you do with that check?
(softly, curious) What?
(passionate) Make it out to cash!
As you like.  (She opens door and  he follows her.)

at the wall, still admiring the painting. Now he draws  painting slightly away from wall and glances behind as if looking for a safe. He allows painting to drop back into  place. Followed by camera, he goes on looking around. He  stops before window, looks out, studying possible entranc and exits.
at desk, still searching.

I can't find that checkbook. I  should have discharged her six  months ago! I really don't know  what to do. Where can I look now?  (Turning to Gaston.)  M'sieu Laval, I'm very sorry, but-- She tops short. Gaston is not there. She sees:

in doorway. She looks mystified. She moves toward him  lightly because:
Gaston apparently doesn't know she is in the room. He is  still studying bed with scholarly concentration. Mariette enters, stops beside him.
(with respect for the bed) Eighteenth century.
(getting it; impressed) Yes!
Early eighteenth century. I should  say around--seventeen thirty.
Right!
(examining headboard) Beautiful specimen.
It is beautiful. But I got a little  tired of sleeping in antiques, so I  gave it to my secretary.
(specially interested as  he learns this is not  Mariette's room) Oh?  (He wants to hear more.)
This used to be my secretary's room.
(with affected nonchalance) I see. (Going very close to  headboard, touching woodwork  with expert hand.)   She must have been very happy here.
(with a smile) Too happy. That's why I discharged  her.
(his eye caught by carving  on one of the posts) Isn't that wonderful!  (He turns to Mariette.)  You see, madame-- (He stops, noticing  something on the wall.)
In the wall is a safe. Camera moves to close-up of safe.
(inspired) Let me tell you something, madame,  as a man who has had all kinds of  secretaries ... I wonder if she put  that checkbook in the safe!
I hardly think so. But let's look.  (She goes toward safe.)

Mariette enters, starts turning knob, lips moving silentl as she articulates numbers to herself. The camera pans he out and stops before Gaston who is now close behind her,  concentrating on the combination.
turning knob back and forth.

Mariette opens safe. Gaston takes a swift good look into  safe, but acts casual in case Mariette turns around.

(rummaging with her hand) No, no. No, it's not here. (Suddenly.)   Oh! What do you think of that?  (She brings out two crisp  packages of bank notes.)  A hundred thousand francs!  (With a half-smile.)  You know, I didn't have the  slightest idea--
(severely) But, madame, you keep a hundred  thousand francs--in your safe--at  home?
(worried) You think that's too much?

(emphatically) No! Not enough!  (With the air of a banker.)  In times like these, when everything  is uncertain, every conservative  person should have a substantial  part of his fortune within arm's  reach.
(nodding with the gravity  of a woman accepting her  banker's advice) That sounds sensible.  (She goes out of the picture,  thinking it over.)
Mariette enters, sits.
Very sensible!
Gaston enters, sits beside her.
(sternly; an uncle) Madame Colet, I think you deserve a  scolding. First, you lose your bag--
(gaily) Then I mislay my checkbook--
Then you use the wrong lipstick--
(almost laughing) And how I handle my money!
It's disgraceful!
(with a flirtatious look) Tell me, M'sieu Laval, what else is  wrong?
Everything! ... Madame Colet, if I  were your father-- (with a smile)  which, fortunately, I am not--
(coquettish) Ye-es?
And you made any attempt to handle  your own business affairs, I would  give you a good spanking--in a  business way, of course.
(complete change of  expression; businesslike) What would you do if you were my  secretary?
The same thing.
You're hired!

Speaking for the board of directors as well as myself, if you insist, in  times like these, on cutting the  fees of the board of directors, then  we resign.
at opposite end. He gets up with an air of authority.
Speaking for Madame Colet as well as  myself--resign!
(haughtily) Very well!  (He hesitates.)  We'll think it over, M'sieu Laval!
of insurance agent at his desk. He is looking over Mme.  Colet's policies.

in a different suit. He begins to calculate with his  fingers and murmurs figures.
(after a moment) Then we'd better increase the  burglary insurance to eight hundred  and fifty thousand francs.
(happily; with a little bow) Thank you, M'sieu Laval!
in the kitchen. Big, fat, motherly looking.
No potatoes, M'sieu Laval?
In still another suit. He is standing, looking stern.
No potatoes!
Yes, M'sieu Laval.
in hall.
(answering a question) No, M'sieu Laval!
A fluffy, pretty little maid in Gaston's bedroom, holding duster.
(playing naughty) Maybe, M'sieu Laval!
of Mariette's feet and legs in gymnasium outfit, shooting down on an angle. Feet rise and camera follows movement  arc-wise, comes to rest on Mariette's face.
(holding the position) Is this what you mean, M'sieu Laval?
erect in sweater, arms folded.
Absolutely, Madame Colet.
Gaston in doorway to his office. Evening; lights are on.  He wears a dark business suit.
(coaxingly) Now, M'sieu Laval, please!
Frankly, madame, I'm too tired.
from Gaston's viewpoint. Mariette, in evening dress, is n landing. From downstairs, the music of a tango and laught of guests.
Don't you want to come down and  join the party? Just a little tango --no? Oh, you with your messy old  papers and contracts and money-money -money--all those uninteresting  things!
in doorway.
They're very interesting to me,  madame. And somebody in this house  should worry about money. No,  madame, really, I have to be up  early in the morning.
of Gaston at window, walking up and down dictating, follo by camera. We hear click of a typewriter.
New paragraph. Furthermore, it is  Madame's wish--
Typing away at an appropriate desk is none other than our Lily. She is demure in a little blouse and skirt.
--that while half of the interest  shall be deposited as usual in  Madame's account--

--the other half, contrary to  custom, shall be delivered in cash  into Madame's personal custody.  (Followed by camera, he  goes to Lily and takes  her in his arms.)  Darling, that means that on the  second of June we'll have eight  hundred and fifty thousand francs.
(ecstatically) And her jewelry is worth a fortune!
No jewelry! Hands off jewelry! If  we're broke--all right. I might  pick up a million-franc necklace.  But in times like these when we're  doing a cash business--why take a  chance on jewelry?
Lily gets up, goes to him.

(the way a wife talks  to a husband when she  wants something special) I know you're awfully busy, and I  don't like to trouble you. But she  has one little necklace--you know,  that one with the seed pearls? It's  so quiet and simple. It would go  just beautifully with my neck.  Gaston takes her in his arms, moved. They kiss. There is knock at the door. They leap into employer and employee  positions.
Come in!
Butler enters.
M'sieu Laval, Madame would like to  talk to Mademoiselle Gautier for a  moment.
Very well, Jacques.
We hear door close as butler goes. Lily turns to Gaston. looks her over, straightens her hair a little, then pulls the zipper on her blouse high up to the neck.
Mariette in bed. Breakfast table. She is reading a magazi Knock on door.
(putting down magazine) Come in.
Lily enters. She is now wearing glasses. (Under no  circumstances shall her appearance be exaggerated. Lily i playing the part of a modest, polite little  secretary.)
Good morning,  madame.
Good morning, mademoiselle.  (She makes a gesture  inviting Lily to come  closer.)
She approaches Mariette.
in bed. Lily enters.
(indicating a chair) Please.
Thank you.
Lily sits on a small chair by the bed. Breakfast table is between them.
(busy at the  breakfast tray) You've had your breakfast--oh,  but of course you have.
Yes, madame. You see, I have to get  up very early.  (Chattering.) My little brother goes to school--  (With controlled pathos.)  You see, Mother is dead.
(pouring her own coffee;  making conversation) Yes, that's the trouble with  mothers. First you get to like them  and then they die.
Lily nods sad agreement. Her glance drops to the floor.
of a diamond ring on floor by bed.
She looks at ring with undisguised desire for an instant. Then she reaches for it.
Lily's hand lifts ring from floor.
Seeing that she has been observed, Lily hands ring to  Mariette.
Oh, thanks.  With indifference she throws it over toward night table o the other side of the bed.
A little jewel box, open. The ring falls in.
She looks toward the jewel box with regret, fingers itchi She pulls herself together and sits on her hands.

Thank you! ... Now, mademoiselle,  the reason I asked you to come--
Two lumps, madame?
Please!  (Lily puts sugar  in coffee.)  Thank you.
(taking a spoon) May I?
Mariette nods graciously. Lily stirs the coffee. Then she sits and resolutely puts her hands under again.
She lifts cup, sips coffee. She looks over at Lily.
Looking downward modestly.

Now, Mademoiselle Gautier--
Yes, madame?

You see--  (She has just picked up  some potato a la Julienne --thinly shredded, noodle-like  and crisp--on her fork. Then  she speaks furtively as she  suddenly remembers.)  Oh, not a word to M'sieu Laval!
About what?
(almost in a whisper) Potatoes. He doesn't want me to eat  them--  (with a little laugh)  and naturally I don't want to upset  him.
(with a poisonous  little giggle) Naturally not!
Slowly her giggle dies out, and she looks at Mariette wit sly contempt.
Now. Uh--mademoiselle--in the short  time you have been M'sieu Laval's  secretary, have you noticed any  change in him?
(on guard) Well--uh--yes and no.
To me he seems rather nervous.
Nervous?  (She takes a chance.)  Um-hum. He smokes too much!
No, he works too much.  (Lily nods with  great relief.)  He's chained to his desk. Too much  detail. Now, if you could take over  some of his work--
(with deadly sweetness) So he wouldn't be confined so much  to his office--
(innocently pleased) Yes! And he would have a little  more time for--
For all the really important  things--
Right!
(rising) I'll do my best, madame, even if I  have to work every night.

(frightened) Oh, no, no, no, no, my dear child!  That's ridiculous. You go home as  usual--five o'clock every day. Now  I'm going to be a little bit of a  tyrant--I insist. It'll be nice for  your little brother, too. Five  o'clock--remember!
Very well, madame. Thank you.  (She starts to leave.)
Lily opens door.
And, my dear--
(turns) Yes, madame?
How much is your salary?
